levels.label: entry
levels.description: Dividing a concrete whole into 10 equal parts to discover tenths using fraction strips or a metre stick.
levels.example_task: Fold a paper strip into 10 equal parts. Colour 1 part. What fraction have you coloured?
levels.example_response: I coloured 1 out of 10 equal parts. That is one tenth, or 1/10.
common_errors: Folding into unequal parts and still calling each piece a tenth
Saying 'one out of ten' but not writing 1/10

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Counting in tenths on a number line and recognising that 10/10 = 1 whole.
levels.example_task: Count in tenths from 0 to 1 on a number line. What is 7/10? Where does it go?
common_errors: Saying that 10/10 is 'ten tenths' but not recognising it equals 1
Placing 7/10 before 5/10 on the number line

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Connecting tenths to division by 10 and counting in tenths beyond 1 whole.
levels.example_task: What is 3 divided by 10? Count in tenths from 8/10 to 14/10.
common_errors: Thinking 3 / 10 = 30 (multiplying instead of dividing)
Not knowing how to count past 10/10 (stopping at 1 whole)

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Connecting tenths to measurement contexts and reasoning about their size relative to other fractions.
levels.example_task: A metre stick is divided into 10 equal parts. How long is each part in centimetres? Is 1/10 of a metre greater or less than 1/4 of a metre? Explain.
levels.example_response: Each part is 100 cm / 10 = 10 cm. 1/10 of a metre = 10 cm. 1/4 of a metre = 25 cm. So 1/10 < 1/4 because dividing into more parts makes each part smaller.
common_errors: Saying 1/10 > 1/4 because 10 > 4
Not knowing that 1 metre = 100 cm to complete the calculation

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Finding unit fractions of sets of objects by equal sharing using concrete manipulatives.
levels.example_task: Find 1/3 of 12 counters by sharing them equally into 3 groups.
levels.example_response: 12 counters shared into 3 groups = 4 counters in each group. 1/3 of 12 = 4.
common_errors: Sharing into unequal groups
Giving the total instead of one group's count

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Finding unit fractions of quantities using division, and placing unit fractions on a fraction wall or number line.
levels.example_task: Find 1/5 of 20. Place 1/5 on a number line between 0 and 1.
levels.example_response: 1/5 of 20 = 20 / 5 = 4. On the number line, 1/5 is between 0 and 1/2, closer to 0.
common_errors: Dividing by the wrong number: 20 / 1 = 20 instead of 20 / 5
Placing 1/5 after 1/2 on the number line (thinking it is a large fraction)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Comparing unit fractions and explaining that larger denominators make smaller parts.
levels.example_task: Put these fractions in order from smallest to largest: 1/2, 1/8, 1/4, 1/3.
levels.example_response: 1/8, 1/4, 1/3, 1/2. The larger the denominator, the smaller the fraction, because you are splitting the whole into more parts.
common_errors: Ordering by denominator size and getting it backwards: 1/2, 1/3, 1/4, 1/8
Not being able to explain why 1/8 < 1/4

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Finding non-unit fractions of sets using concrete grouping: first finding the unit fraction, then taking multiple groups.
levels.example_task: Find 2/5 of 15 counters. First find 1/5, then take 2 groups.
common_errors: Finding 1/5 correctly but forgetting to multiply by 2 (answering 3 instead of 6)
Dividing by 2 and then by 5 instead of dividing by 5 and multiplying by 2

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Finding non-unit fractions of quantities using the divide-then-multiply strategy, with pictorial fraction bars.
levels.example_task: Find 3/4 of 20. Show this on a fraction bar.
levels.example_response: 1/4 of 20 = 5. 3/4 of 20 = 3 x 5 = 15. On the fraction bar: 20 split into 4 equal parts (5 each), 3 parts shaded = 15.
common_errors: Finding 1/4 of 20 = 5 but then adding 3 instead of multiplying (5 + 3 = 8)
Shading 3 out of 4 parts on the bar but not calculating the total value

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Finding non-unit fractions of quantities abstractly and placing non-unit fractions on a number line.
levels.example_task: Find 5/8 of 40. Where would 5/8 sit on a number line between 0 and 1?
levels.example_response: 1/8 of 40 = 5. 5/8 of 40 = 5 x 5 = 25. On the number line, 5/8 is between 1/2 (4/8) and 3/4 (6/8), just past halfway.
common_errors: Dividing by the numerator instead of the denominator: 40 / 5 = 8, then 8 x 8 = 64
Not being able to place 5/8 relative to 1/2

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Solving problems requiring finding non-unit fractions and reasoning about what fraction remains.
levels.example_task: There are 24 sweets. Priya eats 3/8 of them. How many are left? What fraction is left?
levels.example_response: 3/8 of 24 = 3 x 3 = 9 sweets eaten. 24 - 9 = 15 left. Fraction left: 8/8 - 3/8 = 5/8.
common_errors: Forgetting to subtract from the total
Not knowing that the remaining fraction is 5/8 (complementary fraction)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Using fraction walls or folded paper to see that two fractions can represent the same amount.
levels.example_task: Fold a paper strip in half. Now fold it in half again to make quarters. How many quarters equal one half?
levels.example_response: 2 quarters equal 1 half. 1/2 = 2/4.
common_errors: Folding unevenly so the quarters are not equal
Seeing that 2 quarters fill the same space as 1 half but not writing 1/2 = 2/4

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Identifying equivalent fractions from a fraction wall diagram by comparing bar lengths.
levels.example_task: Using a fraction wall, find a fraction equivalent to 1/3.
levels.example_response: 2/6 = 1/3. Two sixths bars line up exactly with one third bar on the fraction wall.
common_errors: Choosing a fraction that is close but not equivalent (e.g. saying 1/4 looks the same as 1/3)
Not understanding that 'equivalent' means exactly the same value

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Generating equivalent fractions by multiplying the numerator and denominator by the same number, and using diagrams to verify.
levels.example_task: Find two fractions equivalent to 2/4. Show one on a diagram.
levels.example_response: 2/4 = 1/2 (dividing both by 2) and 2/4 = 4/8 (multiplying both by 2). Diagram: a bar split into 4 parts with 2 shaded = a bar split into 8 parts with 4 shaded.
common_errors: Multiplying only the numerator or only the denominator (saying 2/4 = 4/4 or 2/4 = 2/8)
Believing that multiplying top and bottom changes the value

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Using equivalent fractions to solve problems, including finding missing numerators or denominators.
levels.example_task: 3/? = 6/8. What is the missing denominator? Explain how you know.
levels.example_response: The numerator doubled from 3 to 6, so the denominator must also double. 3/4 = 6/8. The missing denominator is 4.
common_errors: Adding instead of multiplying: saying the denominator went up by 3 so it must be 3 + 3 = 6
Not recognising the multiplicative relationship between numerator and denominator

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Adding same-denominator fractions using a fraction bar: shading additional parts to see the total.
levels.example_task: A bar is divided into 5 equal parts. Shade 2 parts red, then shade 1 more part blue. What fraction is shaded altogether?
levels.example_response: 2/5 + 1/5 = 3/5. Three out of five parts are shaded.
common_errors: Adding numerators and denominators: 2/5 + 1/5 = 3/10
Not understanding that the denominator stays the same

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Adding and subtracting same-denominator fractions using fraction number lines or bars, with answers remaining within one whole.
levels.example_task: Start at 3/7 on a number line. Move forward 2/7. Where do you land? Then subtract 4/7. Where do you land?
common_errors: Adding denominators: 3/7 + 2/7 = 5/14
Moving the wrong direction for subtraction

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Adding and subtracting same-denominator fractions abstractly, explaining that only numerators change.
levels.example_task: Calculate 5/8 + 2/8 and 6/9 - 4/9. Explain why you only add or subtract the numerators.
levels.example_response: 5/8 + 2/8 = 7/8. 6/9 - 4/9 = 2/9. Only the numerators change because the denominator tells us the size of the pieces, which does not change. 5 eighths + 2 eighths = 7 eighths, like 5 apples + 2 apples = 7 apples.
common_errors: Adding both numerators and denominators (5/8 + 2/8 = 7/16)
Being unable to explain why the denominator stays the same

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Comparing unit fractions using a fraction wall to see which piece is larger.
levels.example_task: Look at a fraction wall. Which is bigger, 1/3 or 1/5? How do you know?
levels.example_response: 1/3 is bigger than 1/5. On the fraction wall, the third bar is longer than the fifth bar because splitting into fewer parts makes each part bigger.
common_errors: Saying 1/5 is bigger because 5 > 3
Not using the fraction wall and guessing

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Ordering unit fractions from smallest to largest and comparing fractions with the same denominator.
levels.example_task: Order from smallest to largest: 1/4, 1/2, 1/6, 1/3. Then order: 2/7, 5/7, 1/7, 6/7.
levels.example_response: Unit fractions: 1/6, 1/4, 1/3, 1/2 (larger denominator = smaller fraction). Same denominator: 1/7, 2/7, 5/7, 6/7 (larger numerator = larger fraction).
common_errors: Ordering unit fractions by denominator in the wrong direction (1/2, 1/3, 1/4, 1/6)
Confusing the two rules when switching between unit fractions and same-denominator fractions

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Comparing and ordering fractions with justification, using both the unit fraction rule and same-denominator rule.
levels.example_task: Which is greater, 3/8 or 5/8? Which is greater, 1/3 or 1/8? Explain each answer.
levels.example_response: 5/8 > 3/8 because they have the same denominator and 5 > 3 (more eighths). 1/3 > 1/8 because both are unit fractions and thirds are bigger pieces than eighths (fewer parts = bigger pieces).
common_errors: Applying the unit fraction rule to same-denominator fractions or vice versa
Not providing justification for the comparison

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Comparing fractions that require reasoning beyond the basic rules, using benchmarks like 1/2.
levels.example_task: Without drawing, which is greater: 3/5 or 2/7? Explain your reasoning.
levels.example_response: 3/5 is greater than 1/2 (because 3 is more than half of 5). 2/7 is less than 1/2 (because 2 is less than half of 7). So 3/5 > 2/7.
common_errors: Comparing numerators alone (3 > 2 so 3/5 > 2/7 -- right answer but wrong reasoning)
Comparing denominators alone (7 > 5 so 2/7 must be bigger)
